intro: Passerina calycina var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy false heather, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are typically covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it the "hairy" descriptor in its scientific name. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or rocky habitats.
